text:
BRIAN KENNY: Welcoming to
Managing Through Crisis,

the webcast featuring
faculty from Harvard Business

School sharing insights for
managers on how to navigate
through the COVID-19 crisis.

It's May 21st, and
as of yesterday,

Connecticut became the
last state in the US
to take step towards reopening.

The same is true in most
other parts of the world,
with varying degrees of measure.

Health care experts
remain on high alert

and continue to warn that
subsequent waves of COVID-19

are likely to continue
surfacing around the world

until we find an effective
vaccine or treatment.

And with economic disaster
looming on the horizon,

political leaders are
sweeping away barriers

to drug testing and approval
and encouraging pharma companies

to redirect all their
efforts to finding a cure.
But at what cost?

Today, we're fortunate
to have Kathy Giusti here

to talk about the
implications, good and bad,

that the rush for
a cure is having on
the rest of medical science--

including researchers, doctors,
and most importantly, patients.

Kathy is a senior fellow and
co-chair of the Kraft Precision

Medicine Accelerator at
Harvard Business School.

She's also the founder of
the Multiple Myeloma Research

Foundation and the Multiple
Myeloma Research Consortium.
Boy, that's a mouthful.

Kathy, thank you for
joining me today.

KATHY GIUSTI: Thank
you for having me.
Great to see you, Brian.

BRIAN KENNY: I knew I
was going to stumble over
some of those things.

There's a lot of
words in those titles,
but they're all important ones.
KATHY GIUSTI: Yeah.

BRIAN KENNY: So I'd love
for you to start just

by telling us a little bit about
the Multiple Myeloma Research

Foundation, the work
that you're doing there.

And also the Kraft Precision
Medicine Accelerator
at Harvard Business School.
KATHY GIUSTI: Sure.

So the Multiple Myeloma
Research Foundation,

I founded that with my
twin sister in 1998.
So a long time ago.

And back then, Brian,
it's interesting,

there were not that many
research foundations.

As a matter of fact, I
remember spending a lot of time

with Bob Bell at the Cystic
Fibrosis Foundation and Debbie

Brooks at the
Parkinson's Foundation.

And I think between
the three of us,

we really did shift
the nonprofit sector

to really look at the research
side, which we have loved.

And I think it's made
a huge difference.

The beauty of the MMRF and the
thing it has become known for

is its disruptive
business models.

And I say that because we
were the first to build

a collaborative tissue bank,
which now has 4,000 samples.

We were the first to sequence
our genome with the Broad
Institute.

We were the first to
build a clinical network.

We started four centers,
now it's 25 centers.

And we were the first to
actually put all of our data

in the public domain with
a study called Compass.

And I think all of
those business models

that we created somewhat
disrupted the space,

but they also drove toward
these incredible results.

So think about it, when I
was diagnosed in myeloma,
you lived three years at best.

And today, we can really
look at our patients

and the average lifespan
is closer to 10 years.

And it's a tribute
to the entire myeloma
community working together.

The HBS Kraft Accelerator has
been a joy for me to work on.
An absolute privilege.

What really happened there
was Robert and Jonathan Kraft

gave $20 million to
the Business School.

Because Myra had lost her
battle with ovarian cancer,

and Robert and Jonathan
were wise enough

to know that
business models could

make science and technology
move that much faster.

So as a result of
their endowment,

Dean Nohria called and asked
me if I would come up and work

across all cancers,
all diseases,

and really focus on the
space of precision medicine,

how to drive best practices
forward and make sure

many diseases saw the
same kind of progress

that we were seeing
in multiple myeloma.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

And we're going to come back
and talk a little bit more

about that later in
our conversation, too.

But I'm wondering, you're
at the helm of these two
really important organizations.

You've been plugging away
at this for a long time,
and up comes this pandemic.

What kind of impact
has that had on you

and how you're
leading this work?

KATHY GIUSTI: Well
there's no doubt,

I mean, the pandemic has
absolutely wreaked havoc
on the entire nonprofit sector.

So I've been talking
with a number of CEOs

running many disease
organizations.

And Brian, it's almost like
when you talk with them,

their revenue can be down
anywhere from 25% to 75%.

For some, I even wonder if
they're going to make it.

And a lot of the revenue
decline comes from where
your revenue portfolio is.

For some of us, we
have a mixed portfolio,

where some comes
from events, some

comes from different
levels of donors,

and some comes from
industry partnerships.

If you were highly
reliant on events

and now you're switching
from your galas and dinners

and walks to
virtual events, it's
hard to make that money up.

For the MMRF specifically,
we were very fortunate.

I think our revenue will be
down about 30% this year.

But based off of
our audit committee,

we're always told, no endowment,
but have one year of cash
on hand.

And so, for us, we
also had to look

and say, how much of our cost
is fixed versus variable?

That's the first question
you're going to ask yourself
as a nonprofit in this field.
We're so fortunate.
We never built chapters.

We never had like a
big overhead structure.

We're right in
Norwalk, Connecticut.

A very small, lean
entrepreneurial team.

And so we can be
nimble and flex.

So for the staff and the
team that we had here,

we had to really focus
on a couple things.

One was, make sure
they felt safe

and they knew where
we were headed.

Help them to understand that
in an environment like this,

we were trying to
hold on to their jobs,

but bonuses might be impacted,
salaries might be impacted.

And they were going to have to
change their responsibilities.

And then we worked side by
side with our leadership team.

Again, very fortunate that
we have a very disciplined
strategic plan.

We were able to go through it,
look at the top three pillars.

They were immune,
venture, and data,

and decide together which
ones could really move forward

in a pandemic, which ones were
going to move more slowly,

and which ones might
be placed on hold.

And so we really had everybody
on the team work side

by side with us to make sure
that we focused on anything

that we could move forward and
keep the company moving forward

despite some people
feeling like there's

a bit of a loss of
control out there.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

I mean, these are
hard strategic choices

that leaders make in times
like this and probably

really amplified in
this kind of situation.

We've heard a lot,
Kathy, about people

being fearful of
going in for treatment

for the normal ailments
that people have,

whether that's people that have
heart conditions or people that
are dealing with cancer.

I'm wondering what
your observations are

about the impact on this for
patients in both the short term
and maybe in the longer term.

KATHY GIUSTI: It's been
really hard on the patients.

And I think running
a disease foundation,

you also have to realize
that a lot of our patients
are at the highest risk.

So along with working
with all of our employees,

we had to make sure we
were immediately in touch

with all of the
patients we serve.

And all of the
nonprofits, especially

those focused on oncology
and other diseases,
had to be on their game here.

Again, we were
incredibly fortunate

that we have a chief
medical officer on staff

here at the Myeloma
Research Foundation.

He is also on staff
at Mount Sinai.
His name is Dr. Cho.

We were lucky that he was able
to get right on his iPhone

and tape to our patients
exactly what they needed to do,

which was, don't go to the
hospital unless you have to.

In today's world,
absolutely use telemedicine.

The second was, if you're on
a drug that's an infusion,

we may need to move
you to an oral therapy.

If you're on a clinical trial,
the same thing might happen.

And for some patients,
you might have

to wait to get your treatment
like a stem cell transplant.

They just weren't
happening over time.

Now what's going on
is we had to come back

and via film, directly talking
to all of our patients,

help them to know the
other piece that I think
was hard for them to hear.

And that was, the current
clinical trials in oncology
are on hold.

And even the ones that were
sitting in our pipeline,

like some of these really great
immunotherapy drugs, the pharma

companies and biotech
companies have

to go back and look at their
portfolios and make sure

they understand what's going to
move first in a COVID-19 world.

So we feel like
it's so important

to be transparent
with your patients
and let them know that.

But on the other hand, I
would say the good news
for us is our antennae are up.
Our radar is on.

And we're looking for
every single idea that's

coming out of this
pandemic that we

say that could drive and
accelerate what we want
to do in immunotherapy faster.

So as soon as we
can move, we have

a lot of ideas of how we can
move a lot faster to make up
time for our patients.

And we really want
them to know that.

BRIAN KENNY: Are
there any concerns

on your end about
the impact that this

will have as we siphon funds
into finding a treatment
for this virus or a cure?

Will that take money away
from other research efforts?

Is there a fixed
pie, and we have

to worry about
where the slices go?

KATHY GIUSTI: There's
always a fixed pie.

I mean, there's only so
much money that people have.

And I think what's going on
now is it's forcing everybody

to be really focused on
what they need to get done.

And I think for us, to
give you an example, Brian,

we felt like we had
to let our staff

and our patients know that
we were going to move forward

on one of the most
disruptive initiatives

that we were ever
taking on at the MMRF.

And initially, this launch of a
program that we call CureCloud
was going to happen in May.

Now it is-- and I'll talk
a little bit about it,

but it is a $30 million
to $40 million initiative.

Right, so we have to
take a risk and believe

that we will raise the
money around CureCloud
now and get it off the ground.

And so we took that
risk, and we're

literally on the phone virtually
with all of our investors,

talking with them about
the need for this program

and why we really hope
they'll still support it.

It's a whole new world
of talking to your donors

and investors,
because you're not

flying all over
the country, you're

sitting with them, just
like, we are on Zoom
and chatting with them.

But for us, we felt that
it was critical to launch
in the pandemic.

Initially it was going to
be at the end of May face
to face, big hoopla.

Instead, now it will
be the middle of July,
and it will be virtual.

But this program
that we're launching
is so critical to a cure.
It's called CureCloud.

And to give you just an idea of
how innovation can move forward

even in a pandemic, first, it
has a blood biopsy component

to it that we developed
with the Broad Institute.

Meaning, when we talk
with our patients,

they don't have to get
a bone marrow biopsy.

We have a phlebotomist go to
their home, collect the blood,

and it gets shipped to
the Broad Institute.

And we pay to
sequence their genome.

Once their genome
gets sequenced,

we also pull their
electronic health record
and their immune data.

And we put all of that into
one data set and a clear grade

report for them, which means
it's the highest quality.

They get that report, now they
can go talk to their doctor

and have this amazing
conversation about specifically
what kind of myeloma they have.

And then the third part is we
created an entire visualization

for them, a dashboard
where they can

talk to anybody and everybody
that's in their community.

So as we talked about this
precision medicine world,
it is data-driven.

We had to go get the
data as fast as we can,

and we need these
patients to support us.

But hopefully it's all of these
patients come in on the launch

side, we'll start to be able
to answer their questions
that much faster.

And I think for us,
that was so critical.

We knew we could move it
forward in the pandemic.

We knew we could do a lot
of this work virtually.

But I think that's
what really going
to go give our patients hope.
I think it gives our team hope.
Like, let's keep going.
We have to.
It's urgent.

BRIAN KENNY: Yeah, it's
definitely a bold move.

And it makes me
wonder, you mentioned

before that you've
got your antennae up
for looking for opportunities.

Which makes perfect
sense, I think,
in this kind of a situation.

Are there parallels that
you see that are playing out

with the COVID-19
research, this rush to find
a vaccine, and cancer research?

Are there things that you
can learn from each other

and maybe approaches
that you can share?

KATHY GIUSTI: I'm so
glad you asked me that.

There are so many
parallels, Brian.

I would say the first
two observations

you have to make right off
the bat is, number one,

COVID-19 has shed a light
on a very broken system.

So going back to
the beginning, I

can tell you that
people like myself,

Debbie Brooks, Bob Bell,
would have told you

after decades of doing this
that the health care system is
large, vast, fragmented.
And the incentives don't align.

There's reasons why it
is hard to find cures
and vaccines for COVID-19.

It is not easy, and it's not
easy in oncology or neurology,
either.

But what we do see in COVID-19
that I find incredibly striking

is that when the world
knows the urgency, when
there is a deadline.

Because 100,000
people could die.

Because so many people
are losing their job.

When there is a deadline on it,
you see three important things.

The first thing you see
going on is all the decisions

are being made at
the highest of level.
It's the CEOs.
It's the head of NIH.
It's the head of FDA, CDC.

It's these people that can make
decisions that are making them.
And they're making them quickly.

That is how you want
to play the game.

You want to get decisions
made as fast as possible.

The second is you're seeing
this incredible collaboration.

And I think some
of it is happening

across the academic centers
and pharma companies naturally.

But I think it's also
amazing watching groups
like Gates or Rockefeller.
Even Duke Margolis is coming in.

These are really, really
smart third party advisors

fostering collaboration
and doing beautiful work
and also offering funding.

And then the third thing is
it's always about the money.

When there is a boatload
of money to be had,
risks will be taken.

And everybody will
take a shot on goal.
Because you won't get penalized.

You'll still get funded for
trying to create a vaccine,
trying to create a drug.

And I think that
has taught us one

of the most important
things we will ever

see in drug development, and
that is working in parallel
instead of sequentially.

So everything you're
seeing right now

is everybody trying to
work in parallel instead
of sequentially, and I love it.

If you take the drug
development piece apart

and you say, well, let's break
it out into testing, treatment,

and prevention, which, if you
listen to the news every day,

that's the way they keep
focusing on it, on testing,
what are you really hearing?

You're hearing that we need one
platform of standardized bio

specimens and standardized
data that we can all

use to understand
which diagnostic
is going to work best.
We didn't have that in COVID-19.

By the way, it's why
we're launching CureCloud.

Most organizations and
diseases don't have that.
And it's really important.

When you look at the treatment
side, what you're seeing things
are off label drugs being used.
Which is great.

Expanded access with
data following it.

Master protocols with adaptive
designs which will help us

identify new drugs faster,
but also combinations faster.

And then you're seeing
things like patients

are going to enroll
in clinical trials,

because you're attracting
them from digital advertising.

You're also using
telemedicine to make it easier
to keep them in the trial.
And then move to prevention.

Now we've got great science like
Moderna with an RNA vaccine.

But think about prevention
and just the people.

If you're looking at that
from an oncology standpoint,

you're saying to
yourself, imagine

what the world would look
like if every patient followed
the screening guidelines.
If they didn't smoke.
If they watched their weight.

If they even got the flu shot
and the pneumococcal vaccine
when they were supposed to.

All of these things are
behaviors that everybody

should be watching right
now and taking advantage of.

Because COVID-19
is showing us what
happens in an urgent world.
Well, you know what?

Oncology, Alzheimer's,
all of these diseases
are pretty urgent, too.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah, yeah.

I think we've become
just maybe numb to them
a little bit over time.

But what you're describing
sounds like a new paradigm
that might be emerging.

And I guess so
much of the system
is built around risk aversion.

We want to protect patients,
so we do a lot of testing.

Are we starting to see
some of that risk aversion
melt away a little bit?

And maybe a little
bit more openness

to accelerating things
and taking some chances
that we might not have before.
KATHY GIUSTI: I hope so.

And I can say that we had
a board meeting yesterday
at the MMRF.

And our focus there was, get the
blank sheet of paper out again

and look at
everything, every trend

that is happening in COVID-19,
post COVID-19, and rewrite
the plan.

I think what's amazing
about all of that

is the timing on
another launch that I've

had the joy of working
on up at Harvard Business
School with Richard Hamermesh.

And that goes back to
the Kraft Accelerator,

where, again, we had 300 of
the best people in the country

on precision
medicine that worked

from direct to patient, to data,
to clinical trials, to venture.

They all joined us over and over
again up on the campus at HBS.

And one of the
things we did see was

a lot of the organizations,
especially the disease

organizations, lacked
a strategic plan.

So for Richard and me, we spent
the last six months writing

a precision medicine
curriculum to launch online so

that any nonprofit,
any board member,

any pharmaceutical
or biotech company

supporting these cure seeking
organizations could benefit.

They can literally go
into the curriculum,

see every tool we developed,
how we've written the MMRF

strategic plans, every
white paper ever written

across our work streams
on the Kraft Accelerator,

every Harvard Business
Review article Richard

and I have written
and every case

study we've done in
precision medicine.

And it's all ready for
them with a bow around it,

and that is launching
at the end of June.

And so, again, these
were huge opportunities

that, for Richard and me,
we wanted to get it done
and we wanted to accelerate it.

Because right now is the time
that every nonprofit, including

the MMRF, should be
re-evaluating everything
it's doing.

Because, again, your
antennae should be up.
Things should be changing.

You should be watching what's
happening in the system

and become a better leader
and a better organization.
BRIAN KENNY: Yeah.

Your timing's pretty good
on that by the way, Kathy.
KATHY GIUSTI: Yeah, I know.
It was excellent.

BRIAN KENNY: You speak with
such authority on this.

I really want to thank
you for your time today.

I have one last
question for you.

I'm sure we have people who are
watching this who are either

cancer patients themselves or
they have a loved one who's
dealing with the disease.

Is there anything you
might say to those folks

as they work their way through
this pandemic situation
that we're all faced with?

KATHY GIUSTI: Yeah, I always
tell patients the same thing,

and it's kind of a
mantra that is always
in the back of my head.

It's a program we
actually worked on up
at HBS called the Right Track.

And that is, it doesn't
have to be complicated.

When you move through your
cancer or disease diagnosis,

you have to get
to the right team,

and that means a doctor
who sees a lot of patients
with your disease.

You have to get the right
tests, and that means,

go in and ask for the
genomic or immune testing

so you know exactly
your subtype.

And then get the right
treatment or get on a trial.

And all along the way,
share every bit of data

you can, because
it will help you,

and it will help
others to find a cure.

And the other message I
always try to give to patients
is, don't ever give up.

I mean, I was diagnosed
years and years ago at 37

and told I would never see my
daughter go to kindergarten.

And now, I have
two adult children
and have lived an amazing life.

You never know what a
year in today's world,

where science and technology
is moving this fast,

a year could potentially
buy you a lifetime.
So don't ever give up.

BRIAN KENNY: Yeah, you've
live an amazing life

and helped a lot of other
people in the process
and continue to do so.

I guess one last thing is,
how can people find out more

about MMRF or the Kraft
Precision Accelerator?

I assume they can find those
things on the internet?
KATHY GIUSTI: Exactly.
They just go to--

Google HBS Accelerator and
MMRF, and both will come up.

BRIAN KENNY: Kathy
Giusti, thanks
so much for joining me today.

KATHY GIUSTI: Thanks,
Brian, for having me.
